questions.text: Comment on diagnosis of this ECG?
questions.solution:
The figure shows Mobitz type II second degree heart block. First degree heart block is PR prolongation.

Mobitz Type I second degree heart block: progressive PR prolongation until one p wave is not conducted. Wenckebach's phenomenon.

Mobitz type II second degree heart block: Fixed PR interval and a p will be non conducted. Complete heart block: Complete interruption of conduction from atria to ventricles. pp interval will be constant and RR interval will be constant. No relation between p and QRS.

questions.text: In mitral stenosis loud S1 becomes soft in all of the following except?
questions.solution: Marked calcification, associated MR and bradycardia are causes of soft S1 in MS

questions.text: Which drug is not used in the rhythm disorder shown below?
questions.solution:
Agents that are used for acute rate control in AF are-IV beta blocker and rate limiting CCB Agents used for cardioversion is IV amiodarone, Ibutilide and procainamide

Agents used for oral cardioversion Propafenone and Flecainide.

questions.text: Comment on ECG shown below-
questions.solution:
The ECG shows bigeminy, where one sinus rhythm is followed by one ventricular ectopic. Multifocal atrial tachycardia is characterized by irregular rhythm with p waves having different morphology.

Ventricular tachycardia is characterized by broad complex tachycardia.

questions.text: Perioral numbness and tingling is caused by all except?
questions.solution: Peri oral numbness is due to hypocalcemia, of the given options Vitamin D toxicity causes hypercalcemia.

questions.text: A 30yr old patient with dyspepsia and epigastric pain for the past 6 months has completed a triple regimen for H.Pylori. Which of the following is the best investigation for determining success of treatment?
questions.solution: The test for confirming eradication of H pylori after treatment is the Urease Breath test. Also, the urea breath test is used to detect Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori)

questions.text: What is the grade of dyspnea in a cardiac patient with breathlessness on going to the Washroom?
questions.solution: Dyspnea on exertion at less than ordinary activity is NYHA grade 3

choices.text: Chloride ion and deletion of phenylalanine at 508 positions
Chloride ion and deletion of tryptophan at 508 positions
Chloride ion and deletion of phenylalanine at 708 positions
Chloride ion and deletion of tryptophan at 708 positions

questions.text: CFTR gene mutation involves which ion and which mutation?
questions.solution:
The gene product responsible for CF is CFTR, which serves as an anion channel in the luminal surfaces of epithelial cells, where it regulates the volume and consistency of exocrine secretions.

CFTR mutations lead to abnormally thick secretions. In the lung it leads to recurrent infections.

In the pancreas, it leads to the obstruction of the pancreatic duct leading to malabsorption and steatorrhoea.

Obstruction of intrahepatic bile duct leads to cirrhosis, in males it leads to involution of vas deferens and infertility.

CFTR mutations:

Class I mutation: Absence of synthesis of CFTR. CFTR nonsense mutations like G542X, R553X, or W1282X are examples.

Class II mutation: Defective protein maturation and premature degradation. F508 deletion. Most common mutation. Lumacaftor and Tezacaftor repair CFTR misfolding and promote cell surface localization of F508 CFTR. Elexacaftor, is a third generation molecule effective for F508 as well as a variety of other CFTR mutations.

Class III: Disordered gating, ATP binding or hydrolysis. G551D, leads to inability to transport Cl or HCO3. Ivacaftor overcomes the defect. Approved for 96 other variants apart from G551D.

Class IV: Defective conductance through the pore.

Class V: A reduced number of CFTR transcripts.

Class VI: Accelerated turnover from the cell surface.

Ivacaftor tezacaftor and Elixacaftor are approved as triple combination therapy for CF. it benefits >90% cases with the disease. Improvements in FEV1, fewer infections, improvement in QOL and diminished sweat chloride levels. Designated as Highly Effective Modulator Treatment.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with thalassemia major is brought with a history of requirement of multiple transfusions in the last 6 months. Which of the following is the best investigation for determining iron overload?
questions.solution:
The degree of increase in total body iron stores can be assessed by

  1. Measurement of serum iron and the percent saturation of transferrin (or the unsaturated iron-binding capacity),
  2. Measurement of serum ferritin concentration,
  3. Liver biopsy with measurement of the iron concentration and calculation of the hepatic iron index, and
  4. MRI of the liver.

The serum ferritin concentration is usually a good index of body iron stores, whether decreased or increased

questions.text: Cyanotic heart disease with increased pulmonary blood flow is seen in?
questions.solution:
Cyanotic heart disease with decreased pulmonary blood flow: TOF

Pulmonary atresia with intact ventricular septum Tricuspid atresia

Double outlet right ventricle

TGA with Pulmonary stenosis and VSD Ebstein anomaly

Cyanotic heart disease with increased pulmonary flow:

D TGA

D TGA with intact ventricular septum TGS with VSD

L TGA

DORV with PS

DORV with malposition of arteries (Taussig Bing anomaly) Total anomalous pulmonary venous return

Tricuspid atresia Single ventricle

Hypoplastic left heart syndrome

questions.text: HIV positive patients present with loose stools for the past month. Stool sample was stained with kinyoun stains and oocysts of size 4-6 were seen. Which organism is responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Cryptosporidium: round oocyst 4-6 microns

Cystoisospora: 24-36 microns

Elliptical Cyclospora 8-10 microns rounded

questions.text: Drugs given preoperatively to reduce bleeding intra-op in case of hyperthyroidism?
questions.solution: Potassium iodide is used for controlling bleeding by reducing the vascularity of the gland and reducing the risk of thyrotoxic crisis. SSKI 1-2 drops TID 10 days prior to surgery after controlling thyrotoxic symptoms with anti thyroid drugs in Graves disease.

questions.text: 30-year-old presents with back pain and pain in legs on walking 100 meters because of which she has to take rest and sit down. She also says that claudication pain improves on walking uphill as compared to downhill. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Among the given options Lumbar canal stenosis causes neurogenic claudication

questions.text: A child With cyanotic spells, ESM is left with the 2nd intercostal area. CXR shows?
questions.solution: Cyanotic congenital heart disease with systolic murmur in PA is TOF. CXR will show a boot shaped heart. The toe of the boot is formed by the upward pointing cardiac apex, which makes an acute angle with the diaphragm. The upturned cardiac apex is ascribed to right ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: Correct about presentation of neurogenic shock is?
questions.solution: Neurogenic shock is associated with bradycardia and hypotension. It is a type of distributive shock.

questions.text: Airway pressure of a patient is being measured. At what capacity is the PV curve the pressure recording at mouth will become zero?
questions.solution: In the pressure volume curve. The pressure is zero at a lung volume that corresponds to the volume of gas in the lungs at FRC (ie.., relaxation volume).

questions.text: A person brings his 60-year-old father with complaints of weakness in the left side of body. He says that he shaves only on the right side of the face and does not bathe the left side of body. When asked to draw the clock shown he could draw part of the image. Comment on the site of lesion in the brain?
questions.solution: The condition described is hemineglect. Hemineglect is seen with involvement of non dominant parietal lobe.

questions.text: High anion gap commonly seen in which condition?
questions.solution: High anion gap and normal anion gap are seen in metabolic acidosis

choices.text: FREE T4: LOW; FREE T3: LOW; rT3: NORMAL; Total T4: NORMAL; Total T3: NORMAL; TSH: ELEVATED
FREE T4: NORMAL; FREE T3: LOW; rT3: ELEVATED; Total T4: NORMAL; Total T3: NORMAL; tsh: NORMAL
FREE T4: HIGH; FREE T3: HIGH; rT3: NORMAL; Total T4: HIGH; Total T3: HIGH; LOW
FREE T4: HIGH; FREE T3: HIGH; rT3: NORMAL; Total T4: NORMAL; Total T3: NORMAL; TSH: ELEVATED

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in primary hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
In primary hypothyroidism, TSH is elevated, with low freeT3 and freeT4. Primary hypothyroidism is defined as low levels of blood thyroid hormone due to destruction of the thyroid gland. This destruction is usually caused by autoimmunity, or an intervention such as surgery, radioiodine, or radiation.

Clinical (overt) hypothyroidism is diagnosed on the basis of characteristic clinical features, consisting of mental slowing, depression, dementia, weight gain, constipation, dry skin, hair loss, cold intolerance, hoarse voice, irregular menstruation, infertility, muscle stiffness and pain, bradycardia.

choices.text: Blood pressure >185/110 mm Hg despite treatment
Patient presented at 3 hours of symptoms
CT scan showing no hemorrhage/edema of >1/3 of the MCA territory

questions.text: Patient presented with ischemic stroke. Thrombolysis is contraindicated if
questions.solution: Indications and contraindications of thrombolysis in ischemic stroke.

questions.text: The image was given of a clinician performing an ankle jerk. It is exaggerated in which type of lesion?
questions.solution:
Lower motor neurons are those whose axons terminate on skeletal muscles. Damage to these neurons is associated with flaccid paralysis, muscular atrophy, fasciculations (visible muscle twitches that appear as flickers under the skin), hypotonia (decreased muscle tone), and hyporeflexia or areflexia.

The development of cerebellar ataxia. Upper motor neurons typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons. Damage to these neurons initially causes muscles to become weak and flaccid but eventually leads to spasticity, hypertonia (increased resistance to passive movement), hyperactive stretch reflexes, and abnormal plantar extensor reflex (positive Babinski sign).

questions.text: Which sign is being elicited?
questions.solution:
The plantar reflex is elicited by stroking, with a noxious stimulus such as a tongue blade, the lateral surface of the sole of the foot beginning near the heel and moving across the ball of the foot to the great toe.

The normal reflex consists of plantar flexion of the toes. With upper motor neuron lesions above the S1 level of the spinal cord, a paradoxical extension of the toe is observed, associated with fanning and extension of the other toes (termed an extensor plantar response, or Babinski sign).

However, despite its popularity, the reliability and validity of the Babinski sign for identifying upper motor neuron weakness is limited, it is far more useful to rely on tests of tone, strength, stretch reflexes, and coordination.

questions.text: Presence of which of the following will help to determine HBV-HDV coinfection and exclude HBV-HDV superinfection
questions.solution:
When a patient presents with acute hepatitis and has HBsAg and anti-HDV in serum, determination of the class of anti-HBc is helpful in establishing the relationship between infection with HBV and HDV.

Although IgM anti-HBc does not distinguish absolutely between acute and chronic HBV infection, its presence is a reliable indicator of recent infection and its absence a reliable indicator of infection in the remote past.

In simultaneous acute HBV and HDV infections, IgM anti-HBc will be detectable, whereas in acute HDV infection superimposed on chronic HBV infection, anti-HBc will be of the IgG class.

questions.text:
Child presented with a severe acute exacerbation of asthma with spO2-80%. In treatment of this patient in ER what will you do?
a. Order an urgent CXR
b. Nebulization with SABA for 60 min 3 times
c. Inhaled steroids
d. High flow O2
questions.solution: For severe acute asthma, an emergency Chest radiograph is not indicated. Treatment for severe persistent asthma consists of inhaled corticosteroids. Additional long-term controller medicines, such as long-acting beta 2 agonists (LABA), montelukast or theophylline, are added if asthma is still uncontrolled.

questions.text: A 35-year female presented with acute respiratory distress syndrome. Setting and blood gas values are as follows. Po2 =50 mm Hg, PCO2=38 mm Hg, FiO2 = 90% and PEEP is 5 cm water and I:E = 1:2. Which of the following changes in ventilator settings will you permit?
questions.solution: In ARDS PEEP has to be increased to prevent alveolar collapse at the end of expiration. Increasing PEEP will increase the pressure in the system. This, in turn, increases the solubility of oxygen and its ability to cross the alveolocapillary membrane and increase the oxygen content in the blood.

questions.text: 50-year male presented with left sided hemiparesis. Damage to which part of the internal capsule leads to this presentation?
questions.solution: Hemiparesis occurs when the posterior limb of the internal capsule is affected. The affection of genu causes facial weakness, followed by arm and leg.

questions.text: 10-year-old child presented with hemiballismus with sudden onset wild flailing movement arm and leg. Which part is affected?
questions.solution: The involuntary movement described is hemiballismus. Lesion is in the sub thalamic nucleus. 30-40% lesion is in putamen, thalamus or parietal cortex, Chorea-lesion is in caudate nucleus.

questions.text: A 15-year male child presented with hepatomegaly, involuntary movements, poor scholastic performance. His sister died at 5 years of age. Eye examination is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of hepatomegaly, involuntary movements points to Wilson's disease.

Wilson Disease is an inherited condition that causes the body to retain excess copper. The copper buildup leads to damage in the kidneys, brain, and eyes. If not treated, Wilson Disease can cause severe brain damage, liver failure, and death.

choices.text: Excessive infusion fluids leading to fluid overload

questions.text: A 40-year female has several episodes of vomiting and loose stool. She was managed at the periphery by IV fluids and hyponatremia was corrected. She presented to ER with paralysis, dysarthria, dysphagia, loss of consciousness. What might be the cause?
questions.solution:
Overly rapid correction of hyponatremia (>8-10 mM in 24 h or 18 mM in 48 h) causes Osmotic demyelination syndrome. Hypertonic stress in astrocytes within brain regions prone to ODS, leading to generalized protein ubiquitination and endoplasmic reticulum stress due to activation of the unfolded protein response; this is accompanied by apoptotic and autophagic cell death. Rapid correction of hyponatremia also causes a disruption in integrity of the blood-brain barrier, allowing the entry of immune mediators that may contribute to demyelination.

The lesions of ODS classically affect the pons, a neuroanatomic structure wherein the delay in the reaccumulation of osmotic osmolytes is particularly pronounced; clinically, patients with central pontine myelinolysis can present 1 or more days after overcorrection of hyponatremia with paraparesis or quadriparesis, dysphagia, dysarthria, diplopia, a "locked-in syndrome", and/or loss of consciousness.

Other regions of the brain can also be involved in ODS, most commonly in association with lesions of the pons but occasionally in isolation; in order of frequency, the lesions of extrapontine myelinolysis can occur in the cerebellum, lateral geniculate body, thalamus, putamen, and cerebral cortex or subcortex. Clinical presentation of ODS can, therefore, vary as a function of the extent and localization of extrapontine myelinolysis, with the reported development of ataxia, mutism, parkinsonism, dystonia, and catatonia.

However, even appropriately slow correction can be associated with ODS, particularly in patients with additional risk factors; these include alcoholism, malnutrition, hypokalemia, and liver transplantation.

questions.text: Hypercalcemia is not seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Hypoparathyroidism is associated with hypocalcemia

questions.text: A 30-year-old boy present with fever for the last 5 days. Then he developed drowsiness and a coma. What will be used in treatment based on peripheral smear of the patient?
questions.solution: Cerebral malaria is the most severe neurological complication of infection with Plasmodium falciparum malaria. Presence of altered sensorium points to cerebral malaria. Treatment is IV artesunate.

questions.text:
Old man comes to the ER. In which of the following scenarios further investigation is needed.
a. Worst headache of my life
b. Worsening of headache with diplopia
c. Headache not relieved on 4 hours
d. First severe headache
questions.solution: A, b and d are correct answers. These are symptoms that point to a secondary headache. The two tests used the most for headache are a CT scan (computed tomography) and an MRI (magnetic resonance imaging).

questions.text:
Sign(s) of heart failure?
a. Non pulsatile elevated JVP
b. Orthopnea
c. Dyspnea occurring after 2 hours of getting bed rest
d. Right upper quadrant pain
questions.solution:
The JVP in cardiac failure is pulsatile. Option c is suggestive of PND(Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea). Right Upper quadrant pain is suggestive of hepatic congestion. Shortness of breath with activity or when lying down.

Fatigue and weakness, Swelling in the legs, ankles and feet, Rapid or irregular heartbeat, Reduced ability to exercise, Wheezing are some of the signs of Cardiac failure.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female with a long standing history of constipation, menorrhagia, cold-intolerance and non-pitting edema of extremities becomes drowsy and develops altered mentation. She is non compliant with her medication. On examination pulse rate = 55/min and BP = 110/70 mm Hg. First D/D is?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of uncontrolled hypothyroidism with altered sensorium suggests myxoedema coma.

Myxedema coma has a 20-40% mortality rate, despite intensive treatment, and outcomes are independent of the T4 and TSH levels. Clinical manifestations include reduced level of consciousness, sometimes associated with seizures, as well as the other features of hypothyroidism. Hypothermia can reach 23°C (74°F). History of treated hypothyroidism with poor compliance, or the patient may be previously undiagnosed. Myxedema coma almost always occurs in the elderly and is usually precipitated by factors that impair respiration, such as drugs (especially sedatives, anesthetics, and antidepressants), pneumonia, congestive heart failure, myocardial infarction, gastrointestinal bleeding, or cerebrovascular accidents. Sepsis should also be suspected. Exposure to cold may also be a risk factor.

questions.text: Female patient presents to AIIMS ER. She is a known case of chronic stable angina that comes with severe fatigue and prostration. During the blood sample you notice that blood has a brown hue. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Nitrates used for the treatment of angina can convert hemoglobin to methemoglobin in the absence of CYB5R3 which is needed to reduce methemoglobin back to hb. Other drugs include dapsone and benzocaine.

O2 transport is reduced and reflected by the left-shift in the hemoglobin-O2 binding curve. CYB5R3 deficiency usually affects only erythrocytes (type I), causing a mild disorder; when all cells are affected (type II), a severe disease results. Intravenous methylene blue is the preferred treatment in symptomatic patients with acquired methemoglobinemia and 40-60% methemoglobin. The usual dose is 1-2 mg/kg. Alternative treatment with ascorbic acid is preferable in people who are glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficient. Methylene blue interferes with co-oximetry, reducing the value of co-oximetry for monitoring treatment.

questions.text: Duration of prophylaxis in an 11-year-old child with rheumatic fever without carditis or valvular lesion?
questions.solution: The question asks about the duration of prophylaxis. The child should receive treatment till 21 years of age. So the answer is b

questions.text: Child with this blood report showed hemoglobin of 7.4gm%. MCV and MCH are low, high ferritin value interpretation is?
questions.solution: Microcytic hypochromic anemia with high ferritin in a child is suggestive of Thalassemia. C and d cause normocytic anemia with high ferritin. IDA causes low ferritin.

questions.text: HIV positive patients present with fever and non-productive cough and breathlessness. X-ray chest is normal. On work up LDH is elevated and CD4 count is less than 200. Which drug should be started in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario deals with Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia.

The risk of PCP is greatest among those who have experienced a previous bout of PCP and those who have CD4+ T-cell counts of <200.

Recurrent fever, night sweats, thrush, and unexplained weight loss also are associated with an increased incidence of PCP. For these reasons, it is strongly recommended that all patients with CD4+ T-cell counts<200 should receive PCP prophylaxis.

The standard treatment for PCP or disseminated pneumocystis is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX). Alternative treatments for mild to moderate PCP include dapsone/trimethoprim, clindamycin/primaquine, and atovaquone. IV pentamidine is the treatment of choice for severe disease in the patient unable to tolerate TMP-SMX. For patients with a Pao2 35 mmHg, adjunct glucocorticoid therapy should be used in addition to specific antimicrobials. Overall, treatment should be continued for 21 days and followed by secondary prophylaxis. Prophylaxis for PCP is indicated for any HIV-infected individual who has experienced a prior bout of PCP, any patient with a CD4+ T-cell count of <200 or <15%, any patient with unexplained fever of 2 weeks, and any patient with a recent history of oropharyngeal candidiasis. The preferred regimen for prophylaxis is TMP-SMX, one double-strength tablet daily. This regimen also provides protection against toxoplasmosis and some bacterial respiratory pathogens. For patients who cannot tolerate TMP-SMX, alternatives for prophylaxis include dapsone plus pyrimethamine plus leucovorin, aerosolized pentamidine administered by the Respirgard II nebulizer, and atovaquone. Primary or secondary prophylaxis for PCP can be discontinued in those patients treated with ART who maintain good suppression of HIV (200/μL) for at least 3 months.

questions.text: A 45-year man with hypertension has currently developed diabetes mellitus. Lipid profile shows low HDL with high TG and high LDL. Which drug would be recommended?
questions.solution:
Elevated LDL cholesterol with or without Triglycerides in patients with ASCVD risk, statins are the drug of choice.

Among the given options, Rosuvastatin 10mg is the correct option. The dose of Atorvastatin is 20-40 mg/day to begin with.

questions.text: Hamman crunch sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
The three main causes are

  1. Alveolar rupture with dissection of air into the mediastinum;
  2. Perforation or rupture of the esophagus, trachea, or main bronchi; and
  3. Dissection of air from the neck or the abdomen into the mediastinum.

There is severe substernal chest pain with or without radiation into the neck and arms. The physical examination usually reveals subcutaneous emphysema in the suprasternal notch and Hamman's sign, which is a crunching or clicking noise synchronous with the heartbeat and is best heard in the left lateral decubitus position.

The diagnosis is confirmed with the chest radiograph.

Usually no treatment is required, but the mediastinal air will be absorbed faster if the patient inspires high concentrations of oxygen. If mediastinal structures are compressed, the compression can be relieved with needle aspiration.
